children.value: Here is a presentation and simulation of a model of “Increasing Returns to Scale, monopolistic competition and Trade” based on the Krugman (1979) article by the same name in the
with the following simplifications and adaptations:
model and graph analysis simplified to be similar to Krugman, Obstfeld, Melitz textbook.
We use the linear demand setup from Salop, S. (1979)  “Monopolistic Competition with Outside Goods,”
This is a Jupyter notebook with executable Python code for the graphs and simulations. If you want to execute and interact with the content, scroll down to the code cells and run them sequentially.
Consider a demand curve of the form:

children.html: qi=A−b⋅Piq_i = A - b \cdot P_iqi​=A−b⋅Pi​

children.value: Its associated inverse demand function will be:

children.html: P(qi)=Ab−1b⋅qiP(q_i) = \frac{A}{b} - \frac{1}{b} \cdot q_iP(qi​)=bA​−b1​⋅qi​
TR(qi)=P(qi)⋅qiTR(q_i) = P(q_i) \cdot q_iTR(qi​)=P(qi​)⋅qi​
MR(qi)=Ab−2b⋅qi=P−1b⋅qiMR(q_i) = \frac{A}{b} - \frac{2}{b} \cdot q_i = P - \frac{1}{b} \cdot q_iMR(qi​)=bA​−b2​⋅qi​=P−b1​⋅qi​

children.value: and we can find an expression for the gap

children.html: P(qi)−MR(qi)=qibP(q_i) - MR(q_i) = \frac{q_i}{b}P(qi​)−MR(qi​)=bqi​​
P−MCP-MCP−MC
MR=MCMR=MCMR=MC
bbb

children.value: , the more firm sales fall for a given price rise (i.e. the more elastic is demand).

Each firm has exclusive right to produce a unique product (protected by patent or copyright) but competitors can enter the market to supply similar goods. There is a relatively high fixed cost of establishing a production plant and then a simple constant marginal cost:

children.html: TC(qi)=F+c⋅qiTC(q_i) = F + c \cdot q_iTC(qi​)=F+c⋅qi​
MC(qi)=cMC(q_i) = cMC(qi​)=c
AC(qi)=Fqi+cAC(q_i) = \frac{F}{q_i} + cAC(qi​)=qi​F​+c

children.value: Consumers demand variety. Products are symmetric substitutes in consumption. Salop (1979) constructs a model with linear demands
Assume symmetric demand for each good. Demand for firm

Expanding out the earlier inverse demand equation:
q_i = \left [\frac{S}{n} + b\bar{P} \cdot S \right ] - b P S
children.html: qi=[Sn+bPˉ⋅S]−bPSq_i = \left [\frac{S}{n} + b\bar{P} \cdot S \right ] - b P Sqi​=[nS​+bPˉ⋅S]−bPS

children.value: which we can invert to get an inverse demand curve for each firm.
Monopolistically competitive market with free entry will drive

children.html: P=ACP=ACP=AC

children.value:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from ipywidgets import interact, fixed

plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8-colorblind')
plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = [6,6]
plt.rcParams["axes.spines.right"] = False
plt.rcParams["axes.spines.top"] = False
plt.rcParams["font.size"] = 18
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (10, 6)
plt.rcParams['axes.grid']=False

A = 100000
b = 1/1000
F = 100*1000
c = 30
S = 1*1000*1000
qmax = 100
nmax = 50
q = np.arange(1,qmax)
n = np.arange(1,nmax)

def firm(S =S, F=F, c=c):
    qmax = 15000
    ne = np.sqrt(S/(b*F))
    Pe = c + np.sqrt(F/(S*b))
    qe = S/ne
    q = np.arange(1,qmax)
    plt.xlim(0,12000)
    plt.ylim(0,125)
    plt.plot(q, p(q, A=(S/ne+b*S*Pe), b = b*S))
    plt.plot(q, mr(q, A, b), color='b')
    plt.plot(q, mc(q, c))
    plt.xlabel('q')
    plt.ylabel('P, AC')
    
    plt.plot(q, AC(q, F, c))
    plt.scatter(qe,AC(qe,F,c))
    plt.vlines(qe,0,Pe, linestyle=":")
    plt.hlines(Pe,0,qe, linestyle=":");

children.value: Hence, closed economy countries with larger market size will have more firms/product variety, lower equilibrium prices, and higher labor productivity (since each firm is further down its average cost curve).

P=c+qb′P = c + \frac{q}{b^\prime}P=c+b′q​
b′=S⋅bb^\prime = S\cdot bb′=S⋅b
q=Snq=\frac{S}{n}q=nS​
P=c+1b⋅nP = c + \frac{1}{b \cdot n}P=c+b⋅n1​

children.value:
def mkt_eq(S = S, F=F, c=c):
    nmax = 150
    n = np.arange(1,nmax)
    ne = np.sqrt(S/(b*F))
    Pe = c + np.sqrt(F/(S*b))
    AC = c + ne*F/S
    print(f"n = {ne:2.0f}, P={Pe:3.0f}, q = {S/ne:5.0f}, F/q = {ne*F/S:3.0f}")
    plt.xlim(0,150)
    plt.ylim(0,125)
    plt.xlabel('n')
    plt.ylabel('P, AC')
    plt.plot(n, cc(n, S=S, F=F, c = c), color='b')
    plt.plot(n, pp(n, b=b,  c = c), color='g')
    plt.text(nmax,pp(nmax),"pp")
    ntop = (100-c)*S/F
    plt.text(min(nmax,ntop), cc(min(ntop,nmax),S=S, F=F, c = c), "cc") 
    plt.scatter(ne,Pe)
    plt.hlines(Pe,0,ne,linestyle=":")
    plt.vlines(ne,0,Pe,linestyle=":")
Here we can see the effect of opening to trade (the potential market for each firm now becomes the sum of the country markets

children.html: SSS

children.value: ). Here we suppose four equal-size countries open up to each other (the graph then becomes a depiction of the integrated world market).
The result is lower prices and average cost and a higher number of product varieties

children.html: nnn

children.value:
mkt_eq(S=50000, F=F, c=c)
mkt_eq(S=200000, F=F, c=c)
In the example above each country now sells to the entire world market, so the size of each country’s market in effect quadruples. The total number of firms (and products) goes from

children.html: n=22n=22n=22

children.value: in each country (88 firms in total, but only 22 products) to a world total of

children.html: n=45n=45n=45

children.value: firms and products. Each country now has just 11 firms but each of these firms now has much larger production runs (

children.html: q=4,472q=4{,}472q=4,472

children.value: after opening to trade compared to

children.html: q=2,236q=2{,}236q=2,236

children.value: The price (and average cost) of each product falls from

children.html: 75to75 to 75to

children.value: 52 and the number of product varieties rises from 22 to 45.
